1. "Butters' Very Own Episode" (Season 5, Episode 14) - In this episode, Butters is grounded by his parents and becomes increasingly isolated and depressed. South Park brilliantly balances humor with empathy in showcasing the loneliness that Butters feels, as well as the absurdity of his parents' punishment.

2. "You're Getting Old" (Season 15, Episode 7) - This episode explores the disconnect between Stan and his friends as he grows older and begins to see the world differently. While there are plenty of funny moments, the episode is also incredibly poignant, highlighting the isolating experience of feeling like you don't fit in anymore.

3. "Tonsil Trouble" (Season 12, Episode 1) - In this episode, Cartman contracts HIV after receiving a blood transfusion. While the storyline itself is absurd, the episode manages to balance humor with empathy by showcasing the fear and stigma surrounding HIV and AIDS.

4. "Osama Bin Laden Has Farty Pants" (Season 5, Episode 9) - After accidentally being left behind in Afghanistan, the boys encounter Osama Bin Laden, who turns out to be a bumbling idiot. This episode manages to find humor in a serious and scary situation, while also highlighting the absurdity of war and political rhetoric.

5. "Le Petit Tourette" (Season 11, Episode 8) - In this episode, Cartman pretends to have Tourette's syndrome in order to say whatever he wants without consequence. South Park manages to walk the line between offensive and empathetic by acknowledging the struggles of those who actually have Tourette's, while also poking fun at Cartman's ridiculous behavior.
